ray.rage.scene

Interface Camera.Frustum

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractGenericFrustum, GenericPerspectiveFrustum
    Enclosing interface:
    Camera

    public static interface Camera.Frustum
    A frustum represents a pyramid, capped at the near and far end, which is used to represent either a visible area or a projection area.

    The frustum defines a viewing volume where scene-objects within its bounds are considered to be visible. In other words, the frustum specifies the region of space in the modeled world that may appear on the screen by representing a field of view.

    Author:
    Raymond L. Rivera

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static class  Camera.Frustum.Projection
      Specifies the projection the camera should use.

      • setAspectRatio

        void setAspectRatio(float ratio)
        Sets the aspect ratio for the frustum viewport.

        The width to height ratio of a viewport is usually defined as 1.333333 for 4:3 displays or 1.77777 for 16:9 displays. Mathematically, it's ratio = width / height

        Parameters:
        ratio - The width to height ratio.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If ratio <= 0.

      • getAspectRatio

        float getAspectRatio()
        Returns the width to height ratio of the viewport.
        Returns:
        The width:height ratio.

      • setAutoAspectRatio

        void setAutoAspectRatio(boolean enabled)
        If set to true, the viewport will automatically recalculate the aspect ratio of this frustum whenever it's resized.

        Set this to true only when this object is in use by a single viewport.

        Parameters:
        enabled - True to enable automatic recalculation of the aspect ratio. False otherwise.

      • getAutoAspectRatio

        boolean getAutoAspectRatio()
        Gets whether the automatic calculation of aspect ratio is currently enabled or not.
        Returns:
        True when automatic recalculation of aspect ratio is enabled. False otherwise.

      • setNearClipDistance

        void setNearClipDistance(float nearClipDistance)
        Sets the distance to the near clipping plane.

        The view frustum is a pyramid created from the frustum position and the edges of the viewport, but with its top cut off flat. This method sets the distance between the frustum's position and the near end (or top) of that pyramid.

        The position of the near clipping plane is the distance from the frustum's position to the screen on which the world is projected. The frustum's viewport should have the same aspect ratio as the screen viewport it renders into to avoid distortion.

        Parameters:
        nearClipDistance - The plane's offset from the frustum's position, in world coordinates. This value must be greater than zero and less than the far clipping plane.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If nearClipDistance <= 0 or nearClipDistance >= farClipDistance.
        See Also:
        setFarClipDistance(float)

      • getNearClipDistance

        float getNearClipDistance()
        Gets the value of the frustum's near clipping plane.
        Returns:
        The distance from this frustum's current position to the near end of its clipping plane.

      • setFarClipDistance

        void setFarClipDistance(float farClipDistance)
        Sets the distance to the far clipping plane.

        The view frustum is a pyramid created from the frustum position and the edges of the viewport. This method sets the distance for the far end (or base) of that pyramid.

        Be mindful of the values you choose here. Increasing the ratio between the near and far planes lowers the accuracy of the Z-buffer used for depth testing pixels. An observable side-effect of this might be Z-Fighting.

        Parameters:
        farClipDistance - The plane's offset from the frustum's position, in world coordinates. This value must be greater than the near clipping plane.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If farClipDistance <= nearClipDistance.
        See Also:
        setNearClipDistance(float)

      • getFarClipDistance

        float getFarClipDistance()
        Gets the value of the frustum's far clipping plane.
        Returns:
        The distance from this frustum's current position to the far end of its clipping plane.

      • setFieldOfViewY

        void setFieldOfViewY(Angle angle)
        Sets the vertical field-of-view (FOV) of this frustum.

        The Field Of View (FOV) is the angle made between the frustum's position and the edges of the 'screen' onto which the scene is projected. Typical values are between 45 and 60 degrees.

        The horizontal field of view is calculated from this viewport's dimensions. They will only be the same if the viewport is square.

        Parameters:
        angle - The angle of the field of view.
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - If the angle is null.

      • getFieldOfViewY

        Angle getFieldOfViewY()
        Gets the angle of the vertical field-of-view (FOV) of this frustum.
        Returns:
        The angle measuring the vertical field of view.

      • getViewMatrix

        Matrix4 getViewMatrix()
        Gets the view matrix for this frustum.
        Returns:
        The frustum's current view matrix.

      • getProjectionMatrix

        Matrix4 getProjectionMatrix()
        Gets the projection matrix for this frustum.
        Returns:
        The frustum's current projection matrix.
